Su negocio es la venta de fruta; decenas de camiones llegan diariamente del trópico cochabambino a descargar su producción de fruta de estación, ella tiene un depósito dónde almacena la fruta que es comercializada semanalmente. Su sueño es ampliar su negocio y mejorar sus ventas para mejorar la calidad de vida de sus hijas. Esta es la primera secuencia de préstamos con la institución en siete años que viene realizando esta labor. Ella desea realizar la compra de mayor cantidad de frutas, debido a las fiestas de fin de año que se avecinan y donde las ventas aumentan casi en todos los rubros, su plan es realizar mayor cantidad de ventas aumentando su oferta.
Es por esos motivos que Virginia solicita un préstamo para la compra de fruta por mayor para aprovechar las ventas de fin de año y solventar los gastos de sus cinco hijas.
texts.en:
Virginia is a 35-year-old woman. She is married and has five daughters, ages 3, 6, 9, 11, and 14. Her business is selling fruit. She is a good mother, optimistic, determined, tenacious, strong, responsible, and hard-working. She carries out her business in the town of Sacaba, which supports itself as the breadbasket of the city because of the production of cereals, vegetables, and fruits, even in the urban districts. Corn, wheat, barley, vegetables, fruits, bananas, papayas, oranges, apples, peaches, and even passion fruits are produced in Sacaba. There are also chicken farms, and people work in bee-keeping.

Virginia has a dark complexion, long tied-back black hair, and short stature. Her mother tongue is Quechua, and she speaks Spanish. In her business, she speaks both languages. (She is the first one on the left, wearing an animal print sweater.) She lives with her husband, who works in construction, and their five daughters, of whom four are in school and the youngest is still in her care. The need to generate better economic income to pay the expenses of their five daughters led her to form a communal bank with people with businesses such as neighborhood store, butcher shop, video store, selling sandwiches, handicrafts in plaster, selling soft drinks, and a bookstore in order to apply for a loan and expand their businesses. 

Her business is selling fruit. Tens of trucks arrive daily from the Cochabamba tropics and unload their production of seasonal fruit. She has a storage area where she stores the fruit that is sold weekly. Her dream is to expand her business and improve her sales in order to improve the quality of life of her daughters. This is her first loan sequence with the institution in the 7 years that she has been doing this work. She wants to purchase a larger quantity of fruit, due to the celebrations at the end of the year, which are getting close, and where the sales increase in almost every area. Her plan is to make a greater quantity of sales by increasing her supply.

It is for these reasons that Virginia is applying for a loan to purchase fruit wholesale in order to take advantage of the sales at the end of the year and pay the expenses of her five daughters.

loans.use: to buy fruit wholesale to take advantage of the sales at the end of the year and to pay the expenses of her five daughters.

loans.name: Rubie

texts.en: Rubie is 25 years-old and lives in Gango, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental with her live in partner and has 4 children. To earn a living, Rubie has a retail shop at home she has sold biscuits, noodles, candies, food in pouches and canned goods. This is the only income for the family. She has requested a new loan of PHP 5,000.00 from GDMPC in order to purchase additional products to sell. In the future, Rubie hopes to gain more income from her business to use for the education of her children.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha owns a small stand that sells chickens to the public. She learned the business from her parents and has been in this line of work for over 15 years. Although she earns money from this business and her husband has a humble but stable salary they are often short of money and do not have enough to invest in her business. With the loan money Martha plans to invest in more products and better tools. Currently she begins work at 6 a.m. and usually dedicates 16 hours a day to her business.

loans.use: Invest in tools

loans.name: Enam

texts.en:
Enam D. is married, the mother of two, and has her young son at home. Her main business is selling smoked fish to provide for her family. She has an acceptable income because of the work she does and her disciplined management. But this woman has become the head of household since her husband died two years ago and is overwhelmed with family obligations. To find a way out, she would like to augment her production but lacks the financial means to do so. And so she is requesting financial aid in the amount of $700. This loan will go towards constructing a second oven for producing more smoked fish in order to improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Madame D. Enam est mariée et mère de deux (2) enfants et a à sa charge un petit fils. Son activité principale est la vente de poisson fumé pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. La qualité de son travail et la gestion rigoureuse qu’elle en fait lui procure un revenu acceptable. Mais cette femme, devenue « chef de famille » à la suite du décès de son mari depuis 2 ans, est écrasée par les charges du ménage. Pour sortir de ces difficultés elle veut augmenter sa production mais ne dispose pas suffisamment de moyens financiers. Elle sollicite alors un concours financier d’un montant de $700. Le crédit qu’elle demande va servir à la construction d’un second four et augmenter la quantité de production en vue d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: To construct a second oven to increase her production of smoked fish

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet I. is a 36 year old woman with five children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria, and sells Ogbolo. She is requesting 400 USD to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Dominga

texts.es:
When Dominga was young she worked selling chickens by the pound, but she had to stop because there was too much competition. Twenty years ago she started selling seafood. Her and her husband decided to travel to the coast and bring their products back to the city to sell. She also works selling jewellery and cosmetics. She has managed to combine these two activities and she earns well from them. When she has to travel to buy seafood her daughter attends to her customers. She works weekdays from 9am to 5pm.

With the loan she will buy more jewellery and cosmetics for her clients. She will also buy some dairy products, especially yoghurt, to sell in her local area as people have asked her for this product.

Dominga is married. She is 45 years old and has five children, all of whom are married. Her husband is a merchant sailor and works on a ship. They have a small car and her husband uses it to deliver products when he is free. Her goal is to finish off their house and therefore accommodate her family better. Her and her husband are working hard to achieve this.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Volunteer Translator

Dominga desde joven trabajaba vendiendo pollos por libra. Actividad que la fue dejando por la competencia que había. Desde hace 20 años ella se inicio con la venta de mariscos. Junto a su esposo deciden viajar a otro lado y traer el producto aquí a la ciudad para su venta. Ella además de tener esta actividad trabaja vendiendo productos de bisutería y cosméticos. Ha logrado combinar estas dos actividades que le generan buenos ingresos. Cuando ella tiene que viajar a comprar mariscos su hija se encarga de atender la demanda de sus clientes. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 9 a.m. hasta las 5 p.m.

El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de mas productos de bisutería y cosméticos para satisfacer a sus clientes. Otra parte del crédito comprara productos lácteos como lo es: yogurt. Para la venta en su domicilio y ambulante. Tiene pedidos de este producto.

Dominga es casada. Tiene 45 años y 5 hijos los que ya están casados. Su esposo es marino mercante y trabaja en una embarcación. Poseen un carrito el cual por las tardes su esposo se encarga de realizar fletes cuando esta libre. Su deseo es poder terminar su casita y de esta manera darle comodidad a su familia. Junto a su esposo están realizando esfuerzos para lograrlo.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics, jewellery and maybe dairly products too/Invertir en cosmeticos y bisuteria, y quizas tambien en lacteos

loans.name: Fanta

texts.en: Fanta K. is forty years old, married with five children.  Her husband is also a petty trader but his business is small and this puts Fanta in a position of taking care of the family expenses. Fanta is committed to providing her children with an education and in the future, to build a house for the family.  She runs a business of selling palm oil,  millet,  and nut oil in Kabala town of Sierra Leone.  She is requesting a loan of $275 to increase her stock

loans.use: Increase supplies for small retail business.

loans.name: Glenda Nohemy

texts.en:
Glenda Nohemy N. A. has been making and selling food from her home for 5 years. Sales are greatest on the weekends because she sells Wendish sea soup and Mexican tacos.

Her three daughters help with the cooking. She is requesting this loan of $150 to purchase more ingredients so she can make more food to sell. She plans to use the profit from sales to pay school expense for her daughters so they can have a better future.

loans.use: Purchase vegetables and ingredients for making food to sell

loans.name: Susitina

texts.en: Susitina is a woman of forty-five, married with four kids. She has applied for her latest loan in order to buy all the chemicals needed for her farm as well as for repairing the back of her house which is badly need of repair. Her first loan was used to start up her farm, which is doing well now. She also hopes to repair the roof and the front of her house with her next loan. And she is very thankful for the help she get from this loan program.

loans.use: To buy weed-killing chemicals for her farm and for home improvement

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled is a 31-year-old married man. He lives in the Bekaa with his wife and two children. Khaled is a car mechanic. He is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy tools and materials for his business. Khaled is known to be very dependable. This will be Khaled's fifth loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To buy tools and materials for his auto repair business

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en: K. Zainab lives in the Nausky region. She is married and has 4 children. She has been a client of MicroInvest since 2004. Mrs. K. Zainab is engaged in a home business baking and selling national bread (Lepeshky). She has 9 years of experience in the business. Now Mrs. K. Zainab requests a loan of $900 to purchase flour.

loans.use: To purchase flour

loans.name: Abdukahhor

texts.en:
S. Abdukahhor is 49 years old. He and his wife have raised three children. 

For the last 9 years Abdukahhor has been selling shoes for women in the local central market. Abdukahhor’s son and wife help him in running the business. The wife travels to purchase the goods and his son helps him sell in the market (his son is in the picture). Initially when Abdukahhor started the business, he purchased shoes in a neighboring city.  Now, as the business expanded Abdukahhor's wife travels to China for this purpose. In general the business has been successful generating a stable income for the family. 

Now Abdukahhor plans to purchase more women's shoes. He requests $1,000.00 US Dollars for the term of 6 months.  Already having proven himself as a reliable client Abdukahhor promises to repay the current loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase new women's shoes.

loans.name: Bocc Jeff Group

texts.fr:
We would like to purchase dying products to dye and then sew, embroider and knit clothing in order to make high-quality products that we will sell to tourists, as we live in a seaside region that welcomes many visitors every day. With this loan, we would like to train young village girls in order to keep them from being seduced by the big city and to provide them with training they can use for the rest of their lives. Our goal is to rent a location to use as a training and production workshop. This is a contribution that we will make to the development of our town and also to the fight against poverty, rural exodus and illegal immigration, a problem that has plagued our seaside region. 

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Nous voulons acheter des produits de teinturerie pour teindre les habits. ensuite les coudre, les broder, les tricoter pour avoir un produit de bonne qualité que nous allons vendre aux touristes puisque que nous habitons une zone balnéaire qui reçoit beaucoup de visiteurs tous les jours. Nous souhaitons grâce à ce prêt, former des jeunes filles du village afin d'éviter qu'elles ne tombent dans les mirages des grandes villes et leur donner une formation qui pourra leur servir pour toute leur vie. Ce qui fait que nous allons louer un site pour en faire un atelier de formation et de production. Ceci consiste à une contribution que nous allons apporter au développement de notre localité et aussi participer à la lutte contre la pauvreté, l'exode rural vers les grandes villes et lutter contre l'émigration clandestine car notre zone étant maritime, a été souvent victime de ce fléau.

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, thread and dyes

loans.name: Lucinda

texts.es:
Lucinda is a member of the community bank Mujeres Creatives 2, located at 35 Walter MZ B Lt. Street in Santa Clara, in the disctrict of Manaytay in the city of Ucayali. She is 54 years old and is a mother of 4 children, her husband is a nurse. Lucinda with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos in the amount of S/. 300 decided to invest the funds on the sales of candy lollipops.

Today she depends on the sale of her candy, and she starts day very early to do household chores and make her candy, that she sells from her own home and they have become very popular because they are soo delicious.

With this loan of S/800 which will be repaid in a term of 4 months, she will purchase ingredients such as flavoruings, locally grown fruits, sugar, milk, and small bags to wrap her candy.

Lucinda is very grateful for her loans provided by Manuel Ramos and she is grateful towards her community bank for the support they are providing her.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Lucinda pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Creativas 2, ubicado en la Calle Walter Mz. B Lt. 35 Santa Clara, del Distrito de Manaytay del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 54 años es madre de 4 hijos, su esposo es enfermero, es así que Lucinda con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en la venta de chupetes. En la actualidad cuenta con su venta chupetes, se levanta muy temprano para realizar las tareas domesticas y a la vez prepara sus chupetes que vende en su propia casa y tiene mucha aceptación por los ricos que son. Con este préstamo de S/.800 el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará ingredientes como saborizantes, frutas de la región, azúcar, leche, y bolsas para envasar sus chupetes Lucinda esta muy agradecida a los préstamos que le brinda Manuela Ramos y a su banco comunal por todo el apoyo que le están brindando.

loans.use: With the loan she will purchase ingredients for the preparation of her products.

loans.name: Dang Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Dang Thi N. joined the TYM Fund since 2007. Her husband is a wedding photographer, and she stays at home breeding pigs and chickens. At the age of 49 years old, she fulfilled her responsibility to raise and rear her children. Therefore, she spends her profit in furnishing the house and improving living conditions. After several times of borrowing little money to get to know the Fund’s repaying method, she wants to borrow 450 USD to buy furnitures for wedding rental, making a good connection to her husband’s business. Coming to Mrs.N.’s store, customers can always rent new furnitures with acceptable price. Her family current average income is 150 USD/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Đặng Thị N. tham gia Quỹ năm 2007. Chồng làm thợ chụp ảnh, phục vụ đám cưới, chị N. ở nhà chăn nuôi lợn gà. Ở tuổi 49, chị đã hoàn thành nhiệm vụ nuôi con ăn học, thu nhập làm ra được chị N. sắm sửa đồ đạc và cải thiện cuộc sống. Sau vòng đầu vay vốn thấp để làm quen với cơ chế hoàn trả của Quỹ, ở vòng này chị làm đơn xin vay 450USD để mua đồ cho thuê đám cưới kết hợp với công việc của chồng. Đến với nhà chị N., khách hàng luôn thuê được đồ mới, giá cả hợp lý. Thu nhập bình quân hiện nay của gia đình khoảng 150USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy furniture for rental

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: Nuon P., 28, is married and lives in Kampong Cham province with her young child. She works in a grocery store, making around $2.50 a day, while her husband makes around $5 a day as a doctor. Inflation has caused prices to soar in Cambodia, and recent hikes in the price of oil and rice have created economic difficulties for many Cambodians. Looking for ways to increase her income and combat rising expenses, Nuon P. has asked CREDIT for a loan of $1,000 to buy a motorbike to carry her groceries across town. She needs a way to transport goods from market to store so she can resell them, but the cost of public transportation is too high. She sees this loan as an opportunity to increase her income and to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Samuel Feliciano

texts.pt:
Samuel Feliciano M. is 33 years old, married and the father of 2 children, aged 9 and 5, the eldest of which already goes to school. As well as his children, he supports his mother and 6 brothers and sisters.

Samuel was in school until the 5th grade and had to leave due to his family's financial difficulties. When he left school he went to the land of the Rand (South Africa) to look for a job, but things didn't go to plan as he ended up being the victim of a shooting accident, so he came back to Mozambique where he started the business from which he lives to this day with the help of his wife.

Samuel is a trader who woks from 10am to 4pm and has no employees although his wife does help him. His business consists of selling clothes and drinks. He buys the clothes and some of the drinks in South Africa and purchases the rest in Mozambique.

This is Samuel's second loan from Hluvuku and he has never borrowed from other institutions. He heard about Hluvuku from friends who were already customers.

Samuel's biggest dream is to have another store and to sell more products, thereby increasing his revenue.

Translated from Portuguese by Inês Teles, Kiva volunteer.

Samuel feliciano M. tem 33 anos de idade, casado, pai de 2 filhos com idade entre o maior 9 anos e menor 5 anos, o maior já vai a escola. Para alem dos seus filhos sustenta a mãe e 6 irmãos.

Samuel estudou até 5ªclasse e não continuou por dificuldades financeira da família. Quando deixou de estudar foi a terra do Rand a procura de emprego e por lá as coisas não saíram no primeiro plano onde sofre um acidente de baleamento e assim volta a Moçambique e começa um negocio com qual vive até hoje com ajuda da sua esposa.

Samuel é negociante e trabalha das 10h as 16h não tem empregados tem ajuda da esposa. O negocio consiste em venda de roupa e bebidas. As compra de roupa faz na africa do sul e as algumas bebidas o resto adquira em Moçambique.

Para Samuel este é o segundo empréstimo na Hluvuku e nunca solicitou noutras instituições. E conheceu Hluvuku atraves de amigos que já eram cilentes.

Para Samuel o maior sonho é ter outro estabelecimento comercial e vender mais produtos aumentando assim os seus rendimentos.

loans.use: To purchase more products for his shop

loans.name: Alicia Julieta

texts.es:
Alicia began her business in order to earn additional income. When she retired from her day job, she was unable to earn enough income to support her family. Alicia wanted to help her husband cover the expenses of keeping a home and help her daughters get ahead, because she wants them to have a better quality of life. She began her business in 1998 with a small store, and then retired from her day job in order to spend her time working in the store. This allows Alicia to keep a more flexible schedule and spend more time with her family. She remodeled the front of her house in order to make the most of the space, and her store began to grow little by little, as she supplies better products.

Alicia needs a loan of $800 to buy more groceries. Her store will then be better supplied and she'll be able to provide better service to her clients. Alicia will pay back the loan in 6 months.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

Alicia inició el negocio por la necesidad de suplir el ingreso que tenía por su trabajo en una empresa de la cual la jubilaron por lo que iba a disminuir su ingreso y a causarle problemas económicos. Ella necesitaba apoyar a su esposo con los gastos familiares y sacar adelante a sus hijas, ya que deseába darle un mejor nivel de vida. Comenzó en el año de 1998 con una tiendita, cuando la jubilaron y fue entonces que pensó en ya no emplearme sino poner su propio negocio que le permitiera tener un horario más flexible y poder dedicarle tiempo a su familia. Aprovecheo el frente de su casa el cual acondicionó para empezar y poco a poco fue creciendo y surtiendo cada vez mejor su tienda.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $800 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar más abarrotes que le permitan tener mejor surtida su tienda y poder darle un mejor servicio a sus clientes.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: 23 De Marzo (23Rd Of March) Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de El Alto se encuentra el centro focal de Villa Exaltación  a éste pertenece, la asociación “ 23 de marzo ”, integrada 17 mujeres ansiosas de progresar en sus pequeños negocios.
La mayoría en el grupo son casadas y afirman que necesitan ayudar a sus parejas en la economía del hogar, ya que tienen un promedio de 4 niños , muchas de ellas por distintos motivos, se separaron de su pareja y tuvieron  que hacerse cargo de su familia por lo que necesitan mayores recursos para  subsistir.
La actividad principal en la asociación “23 de marzo” es la costura de edredones, sabanas y también la confección de camisas, ropa deportiva y otros, estas prendas las comercializan al  Perú, las venden al por mayor. Ellas precisan capital para comprar materia prima en mayor cantidad de ésta manera aumentar su producción y generar mayores ganancias para el bien de sus familias.
texts.en:
In the city of El Alto you will find the location of Villa Exaltación. To this area belongs the association “23 de Marzo” (“The 23rd of March”). It is made up of 17 women anxious to improve their tiny businesses. Most of the women in the group are married and they assert that it is necessary to help their spouses with the household expenses. They currently have an average of 4 children each. Some of them, for different reasons, have separated from their spouses and they have to bear the entire load of the family. Because of this they need more resources to make a living. The primary activity in the association 23 de Marzo is making blankets, sheets, and also shirts, sports clothing, and more. These articles are sold in Perú, where they sell for more. They need capitol in order to buy more materials in larger quantities, and by this manner increase their production and generate higher earnings for the betterment of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Funds to buy larger quantities of materials

loans.name: Sabiha

texts.en:
Sabiha has been selling fish and chapati in Zanzibar since 2004. Chapati is a flat pancake often eaten for breakfast or lunch, either plain or rolled up with fruit or vegetables inside. Both chapati and fish are staples of the Tanzanian diet.

Sabiha is 43 years old, married, and has six children. Her oldest child is 24 and her youngest is 3 years old. She works every day from 7:30 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., which allows her to earn a monthly profit of approximately $65. She is hoping that this loan will enable her to purchase chapati ingredients and fish at greater quantities so that she may net an increased profit.

loans.use: To buy more food ingredients to expand her business.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba G. is a single parent and has 4 dependents. She has received schooling through primary level. Aba sells foodstuffs at the new market in Elmina. She has being doing this since 1998. Aba uses her income for the payment of school fees and utility bills. Aba will use the loan to purchase more foodstuffs like groundnut paste for re-sale.

loans.use: purchase more foodstuffs like groundnut paste for re-sale.

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhorn K. lives in Preak Ta Aung Ti Bei village in Kandal Province, Cambodia. She is a mat maker. Her husband, Mr. Yorn Sam Art, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from his plantation, he operates a motorbike taxi. In this business, he now has an obstacle because his motorbike is too old and he usually spends too much money on fuel. To solve this problem, Mrs. Sokhorn K. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband's business. She hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions with this loan. She is 34 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school while the third is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for a taxi business.

loans.name: Mariela Elizabeth

texts.es: La Sra. Mariela tiene 23 años de edad, vive en el barrio Memorial Sandino en la capital de Managua, su esposo trabaja como vendedor, tiene una hija de 3 años de edad. Los planes para su pequeña familia es tener un patrimonio seguro. Doña Mariela se desempeña como Asistente de administrativa en una empresa privada de aseguradora y posee su micro empresa de transporte, el cual tiene dos años de experiencia laboral y en el sector trasporte tres años. Lo inicio con ayuda de su padre sus objetivos para su negocio es incrementar la flota de furgones obteniendo mayores utilidades. Gracias a los préstamos de Afodenic lograra comprar materiales de construcción como: cementos, hierros, bloques, ladrillos y zinc ampliando su vivienda y los sectores de la cocina, los cuartos ofreciéndole a su familia mayores comodidades y protección.
texts.en:
Mariela is 23-years old and lives in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood in the capital of Managua. Her husband works as a vendor and they have a 3-year old daughter. She hopes to build secure assets for their small family. Mariela has worked as an administrative assistant in a private insurance office for two years and has also had her own business in transportation services for 3 years. She started her business with help from her father, with the objective of increasing her fleet of vans for better utility. Thanks to loans from Afodenic, she will be able to buy construction materials such as cement, iron, blocks, bricks, and tin roofing to expand the kitchen and bedrooms of her house, offering her family a more comfortable and secure home.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials to finish her home

loans.name: Saliu

texts.en: Saliu A. is 41-years-old and is married with five children. He sells an assortment of vegetables (carrots, green peas, cabbage, etc.) to retail customers. He purchases the vegetables wholesale and is requesting a loan amount of $350 (N50, 000) to purchase more vegetables to resell. He is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders and to Lapo microfinance for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia has been a firewood and cloth ("khanga"--traditional Tanzanian fabric worn by women--and bedsheets) seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to "Maisha bora" loan group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 20. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood, "khanga" and bedsheets for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Rukia is 23 years old, married, and has one child, age 2.

loans.use: To buy more firewood, "khanga" and bedsheets to expand her business

loans.name: Chrun

texts.en: Chrun P. lives in Pech Sar village in Takeo province, Cambodia. She earns a living as a farmer, cultivating rice on a plot of land that she owns. She faces problems with this cultivation because her field is infertile and she does not have much money to buy rice seeds and pesticides. In order to deal with these problems, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer, rice seeds and insecticide to make her crops more productive. Her husband, Morn Pork, is a construction worker. Chrun P. is 33 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is a laborer who has been hired to thresh rice. Two of her children attend the local school, while the youngest is too young to work or study. She and her husband are pictured in the photo.

loans.use: Purchasing fertilizer, rice seeds and insecticide to make her crops more productive.

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji H. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to buy a grinding mill for the business.  Keji, 22 and married to a nurse, has two children, both attending school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay their school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy a grinding mill for the business.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn M. V., 38 years old, is married to Luduvico an auto mechanic. Merlyn loves to engage in business. Previously, she engaged in various businesses like longganisa; dried fish and vegetables vending. But she earns only a little amount with those goods.

Presently, she is engaged in selling used clothing known as “ukay-okay” to earn a better income. She plans to have a display stand in the public market as she now only rents.

Merlyn hopes someday that she can expand her business and to have additional store outlets. She believes that PAGLAUM and KIVA will continually support micro-entrepreneurs like her.

loans.use: Expand clothing business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary C. is married, has 2 children and has received an education through Senior High School. Since 1997, she has worked as a trader selling items such as red oil, coconut oil and palm kernel oil at Boatse, near Elmina.  While Mary is employed as a trader, her husband works as a fisherman. Mary uses her income to help her husband in paying school fees. Mary will use the loan to purchase more oil for selling. Mary plans to save and reinvest the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: To purchase more oil for selling.

loans.name: Luzmila Adela

texts.es:
La señora Luzmila Adela Suárez López pertenece al Banco Comunal “Cruz de Motupe II” vive en Prolongación Atusparia N° 1590 en la Ciudad de Huaraz, Departamento de Ancash. Está separada, tiene 49 años de edad y es madre de 02 hijos los que aun dependen de ella. Una de las dificultades de su vida es el problema de salud que presentó en algún momento uno de sus hijos lo cual le hizo gastar casi todo su capital y tuvo que empezar de nuevo. 
Con el primer préstamo de s/. 300.00 empezó su negocio con la compra de abarrotes. Su negocio tiene 03 años y es socia del Banco desde hace 1 año.
En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio, posee una bodega ubicada en su propia casa.  Por otro lado, tiene una cochera la cual alquila y tiene un ingreso mensual extra. Con este crédito de s/. 500.00 comprará abarrotes (fideos, azúcar, arroz, etc.), golosinas y gaseosas. 
Hoy se siente más independiente y segura, ya que es ella quien administra su propio negocio y decide sobre el mismo.
Luzmila manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle surtir y crecer en su negocio y  ser más independiente.
texts.en:
Ms. Luzmila Adela Suárez López is a member of the “Cruz de Motupe II” Microfinance Institute. She lives in the city of Huaraz. She is a 49-year-old separated mother with 2 children who still depend on her financially. One of the difficulties of her life is that one of her children had health problems, which caused her to spend almost all of her capital, so she had to start over again.

With her first 300.00 PEN loan, she started her general store business. She has been in business for 3 years now, and has been a member for 1 year. She still owns this general store, which is located in her house. Additionally, she has a garage that she rents out for an extra monthly charge. With this 500.00 PEN loan, she will purchase provisions (noodles, sugar, rice, etc.), candy, and soft drinks.

She now feels more independent and self-confident because she is the one who manages her own business and makes the decisions.

Luzmila expresses her gratitude to Manual Ramos for allowing her to restock and develop her business, as well as for allowing her to become more independent.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Hajji Rashid

texts.en:
Hajji Rashid K. is a 40-year-old businessman. He deals in cosmetics and has been doing this business for seven years in a mass market area in Natete. He is requesting the loan to invest more in his business. That is, to purchase more cosmetics to expand his business.

He has a plot where he wishes to build rental houses. He also wishes to education his children.

loans.use: To invest in his business by purchasing more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida G. is forty-five years old. She is married and has three children: two sons and a daughter. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Dwenase, a suburb of Sefwi-Wiawso, in the Western Region of Ghana. Her husband is a farmer. Vida is a fish-monger. She sells smoked fish. She sells the fish from a tabletop stall at the market square. She also supplies to retailers and food vendors in her community. Vida buys cartons of fresh fish from big cold stores in Kumasi and smokes them herself. She has been in this business for ten years and wants a loan to buy fish in bulk. She desires to expand her business and to improve upon her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fish in bulk.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia A. from the village of Balintawak, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur.  She is 48 years old. Lucia is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Lucia operates a retail flower garden selling flower products to tourists and local community members. Lucia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns PHP 6,000 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lucia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Lucia is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Lucia from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To expand her flower business.

location.town: Pagadian - Balintawak, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es: Doña María Chávez M. tiene 56 años, es casada y tiene cuatro hijos mayores de edad. La señora se dedica al negocio de la compra-venta de mercadería en general. Vende ropa, cosméticos, lo cual distribuye de manera ambulante y también en su casa, Tiene 10 años de dedicarse a esta actividad. La señora dio inicio a este negocio hace  bastante tiempo, sin embargo el negocio lo había quitado. Después, hace 10 años volvió a empezarlo con la venta de productos varios y le ha ido invirtiendo más y más. El financiamiento será invertido en la compra de productos varios, ya que actualmente tiene bastante pedidos pero son de ropa, ya que esta entregándoles mercancías a otras personas. Su sueño siempre ha sido llegar a tener un restaurante con sus instalaciones bien establecidas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria is 56 years old, is married and has four grown-up children. She buys and sells general merchandise. She sells clothes and cosmetics as a roving sales person and also from her home. She has been selling in this manner for ten years. She had previous experience selling merchandise but quit. Afterwards, since ten years ago, she began selling various products and she has been investing more and more in this business. The loan will be used to buy various products. She actually has many requests for her products. The requests are for clothes. Her dream has always been to have a restaurant in a stable location.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Roy

texts.es: Roy tiene 31 años, vive con su pareja y madre de su hijo de 4 añitos de edad, quien es su mayor motivación para seguir adelante. Se dedica a la compra y venta de madera a las distintas empresas que la requieren para hacer diversos trabajos de construcción. Para ello, una vez por semana, Roy tiene que viajar por los distintos caseríos de su zona para comprar la madera y aprovecha ese viaje para adquirir otros productos como pescado, aves y cerdos para venderlos en la ciudad. En esta labor lleva un periodo de 3 años y le va muy bien, pues lo que más le gusta es que trabaja solo, sin la presión de un jefe, además que su negocio le resulta rentable porque la madera mantiene su precio y ya tiene compradores estables. Este es su 5to préstamo con MFP y le gusta de trabajar con su banco comunal porque se siente cómodo y porque hay mucho compañerismo entre todos los integrantes. Con el dinero que viene solicitando comprará más madera para incrementar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Roy is 31 years old and lives with his partner and mother of their 4 year old son, who is his biggest motivation to keep going. He buys lumber and sells it to various companies that need it for their construction jobs. In order to do this, Roy travels to different villages in his area to buy lumber as well as other products such as fish, poultry, and pigs to sell in the city. Roy has been in business for 3 years and is doing very well. What he likes most about his job is working alone because it comes without the pressure of a boss. His business remains profitable because the price of wood has remained stable and he already has an established clientele.

This is Roy’s 5th loan with MFP. He likes working with his Communal Bank because there is great camaraderie among all the members and he feels comfortable with them. He will be using his loan to buy more lumber to increase his sales.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more lumber for resale

loans.name: Zahra

texts.en:
Zahra is a 49-year-old woman who lives in Bourj El Barajneh, in the southern suburbs of Lebanon, with her husband and their three children. Zahra has been working as flower arrangement designer for nine years. She does flowers, trays and many different types of arrangements for all occasions. 

Zahra has requested a loan of $2000 USD from Al Majmoua to purchase merchandise and a car for her work. She will use the car for delivery. Zahra has been a microcredit client for eight years and has always repaid on time. 

Her previous loans have helped her to improve her work. Zahra is special in her work because she does it well and knows how to satisfy her clients’ needs. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. Zahra decided to start her businesses because she wanted to work independently. In the future, she plans to expand her business by opening a shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and a car for her work.

loans.name: Fermina

texts.en:
Fermina C. from the village of Bolinao Aurora, Isabela, is engaged in managing a general store. She has been three years in the business; she retails different goods in her variety store. Fermina is already 41 years old, she is blessed with two children. Her profits gained from her business are used for the maintenance of the business and to support the education of her two children. She wants the business to improve by adding some items that are not yet available in the store.

For this reason, Fermina is requesting the amount of PHP 6,000 from Kiva lenders as additional business capital. Fermina is happy that her husband and children are very cooperative in the maintenance of their business. She hopes someday that through the business, her family may live a progressive lifestyle.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Yorng

texts.en: Yorng V., 37, is married with 2 school-aged children. He resides in Battambong Province with his wife and children. To make a living, he produces quality rice wine and uses wastes from his manufacturing as food for raising pigs. He is able to earn an income of US $3 per day in revenue. His wife is helps him in the business to double his work and earns the same amount of income to him. This couple tries to work hard every day to ensure that their standard of living is improved. Therefore, V. is asking for a loan of US $500 to purchase animal food added to the current animal he has so that his pigs are able to grow up efficiently to reach maximum prices at the market. By doing so, he hopes he will generate extra income for his family to save for the future household use.

loans.use: buy pig food

loans.name: Mrs. Keo Pech Village Bank Group

texts.en: The village bank loan consists of seventeen people and they all live in Peam Ta Aek village in Kandal province. Mrs. Keo P. is the village bank president, as selected by the members. She is a weaver and now she wants to expand her business by purchasing more raw materials to make more mats to sell. Her husband, Mr. Keo Thea, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice. Mrs. Keo P. is 53 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is a construction worker while the other is attending the local school. Mrs. Uon C. and Mrs. Mach N. were not available for the photo so their husbands are shown in the picture.

loans.use: By purchasing more raw materials to make more mats to sell.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly M. is 48 years old and married to Beneto M., who is 51 years old and works as a driver. In the long years of their marriage, they were given five children: Raymund, 21 years old; Benito, 18 years old; Kimberly, 16 years old; Nelson, 14 years old; and Maih Cecilio, 9 years old. One of their frustrations as parents is that most of their children have been able to attain only a low level of education because of they have insufficient income to pay for their educational expenses, especially since they have more children that they need to send to school. Their dream is their other children be able to finish their studies because education is one of the things they needed to fight against poverty.

Nelly and her husband work hard for this. They have two sources of income: she is running a variety store business, and her husband works as a driver. She has been running her variety store business for 10 years now and she really wants it to grow more.

Since she became a member of Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she has used every loan that she received to improve this business. She is a very good member of ASHI. She has been in the institution for 9 years; she started in the year 2000. Now, her 12th loan will be used again for this business: she will buy what her store needs, like sacks of rice, different groceries and many more items that will sell in her store. She is hoping that after buying all of these, her business will be more productive and continue growing.

Aside from dreaming that their children would finish their studies someday, she also dreams of turning their variety store into a mini grocery store so that they will earn more for their family. That is why they will work hard--for the fulfillment of these dreams.

loans.use: To finance her variety store business

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz J. is from the village of Maac in Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 49 years old. Luz is separated from her spouse and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Luz sells vegetables in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Luz is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase new items to sell. This will be Luz's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy new items to sell

loans.name: Allah Kan Dèmè Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Allah Kan Dèmè est composé de six  femmes dont une célibataire et cinq mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames et vivant  dans le quartier Hamdallaye de  la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la république  du  Mali). Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans et 3 enfants. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de leurs activités commerciales et font le commerce d’articles divers.
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt solidaire, elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt en vu de  diversifier et de rentabiliser leur activités. 
Ce prêt servira à acheter, 3 pièces de 30 mètres de bazin blanc, 10 pièces de pagnes wax,  35 habits pour enfants (des layettes, des robes, complet culottes, complet jupes), 20 complets de chaînes, boucles d’oreilles, bracelets et quelques bagues, 12 flacons de vernis  12 crayons d’antimoine, 250kg de riz et 500 kg de tubercules « fabourama ». 
Elles s’approvisionnent la plupart du temps au marché château de Ségou, avec les forains venant de Massigui et à  Niono. Leurs marchandises sont revendues au même marché château de Ségou, les pagnes wax en ambulant dans les quartiers d’Hamdallaye et le « fabourama » au marché de Médine. La vente se fait au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 27.835FCFA qui sera consacré au remboursement des prêts,  à la contribution aux charges familiales, à la participation aux évènements sociaux (baptêmes, mariages, circoncisions et funérailles),  à l’achat  de matériels constituant ainsi petit à petit le trousseau de mariage des jeunes filles et à la constitution d’épargne.
texts.en:
The Allah Kan Dèmè group comprises six women, one of whom is single and the other five married, - the majority in monogomous marriages - living in the Hamdallaye area of the town of Ségou (in the 4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are on average 34 years old with 3 children. They met each other through neighbours and through their businesses, and they sell a variety of products. Having repaid their first joint loan without any problem, they are now on their second loan with a view to diversifying and making their business profitable. This loan will be used to buy 3 pieces of 30-meter long white bazin, 10 wax-printed loincloths, 35 items of children's clothing (baby clothes, dresses, trouser suits, skirt suits), 20 sets of chains, earrings, bracelets and some rings, 12 bottles of varnish, 12 khol pencils, 250kg of rice and 500kg of "fabourama" tubers. Most of the time they get their supplies from the Château de Ségou market, from the fairworkers coming from Massigui, and at Niono. They sell their goods at the same Château de Ségou market, the wax-printed loincloths while walking through the Hamdallaye neighbourhoods and the "fabourama" at the market in Médine. The goods are sold for cash and on credit to both male and female customers. They are expecting to make an average monthly profit of 27,835 FCFA which will be used to repay loans, and also to contribute to household expenses and social events (baptisms, marriages, circumcisions and funerals), the purchase of items which will gradually make up young girls' marriage trousseaux as well as the building up of savings.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various products

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustina is thirty-two. She is married and a mother of two children, both in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in one of the tourist attraction centres in Ghana. Since the community is a coastal town in the region, the majority of the inhabitants are fishermen/women. Faustina is a hairdresser by profession. She has her workshop by one of the streets. She says she has been in business for over thirteen years and wants a loan to buy artificial hair and other working materials to be able to render better services to her valued clients.

loans.use: To buy artificial hair.

loans.name: Sidney Gerardo

texts.es:
Gerardo Solórzano Méndez, Labora como Higienista en el Mercado Mayoreo de Managua, el tiene a su cargo dos hijos, uno se encuentran en edad escolar, es casado, ha trabajado ocho créditos con CEPRODEL durante seis años, en ese lapso ha invertido  8 créditos en la mejora de la vivienda en la que habita gracias a los financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL, el es un excelente Cliente.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de  6 pliegos de  Zinc, el cual utilizara para su casa de habitación ya que las que tenía estaban en mal estado y se pasaba el agua en invierno.
 Para Brindarle una mejor condición de vida a su hijo.
texts.en:
Gerardo S. M. works as a janitor in the wholesale market in Managua. He is married, and has in his charge two sons, one of which is school-age. He has had eight loans with CEPRODEL over six years, and has invested the eight loans in the improvement of his home which he lives in thanks to the financing provided by CEPRODEL. He is an excellent borrower.

This loan is to invest in the purchase of six sheets of corrugated roofing which he will use for his house as his current roofing is in poor condition and leaks in the winter. He wants to provide better living conditions for his son.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home improvements and expansion

loans.name: Nene

texts.en: Nene G. is currently in the business of selling cakes and bread in a shop and is requesting a loan to purchase fresh fruits like mangoes, passion fruits, guava, etc. to make juice to sell. Nene is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a mechanic. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up her shop. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase fresh fruits like mangoes, passion fruits, guava, etc. to make juice to sell.

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en:
Muhabbat I. is 38 years old. She is married with three children. Muhabbat sells clothing for kids and many other small things. She started her business 15 years ago. At that time her husband-entrepreneur supported Muhabbat, providing the funds for start-up. Gradually, the business of Muhabbat expanded. Being hard-working and polite by nature, she managed to obtain a clientele that is happy with the goods and the services. The business generates a stable income for the family. Muhabbat loves her children very much and she wants all of them to be well-educated. Today, she is requesting 5000 Somoni. She is planning to spend the loan on purchasing additional goods for sale. You could become an important part in Muhabbat family's life. She deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving her.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase men’s clothing to increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Nurjan's Group

texts.en:
Among the multitude of people who surround us, it is quite difficult to know that there are people who are in need of little help. Sometimes you are able to help them. and just because you are not familiar with them. you just walk beside these people not even realizing who they are, and therefore reading these stories is a real way to help people.

The heroes of this story are ordinary people from Kyrgyzstan. S. Nurjan, 31, is the leader of this group. She comes from Tokmok, a provincial town in the north of Kyrgyzstan. She is married and has two sons. Her husband works in the military; he is a foreman. Both of Nurjan’s sons were too little to go to school and Nurjan had to stay at home and look after the children. Nevertheless, Nurjan’s sister advised her to start a trade in something, so about two years ago, Nurjan started trading in shoes and socks. Now she has a stable income of about seventy dollars per month. This has allowed her to save some funds and buy some items of furniture for the house. Nurjan is in need of a loan. She would like to invest some funds that would help her to buy more kinds of shoes and socks, which in turn would boost her sales. In near future she is planning to buy a car. Her plans go as far as to buy a three–room flat.

These people are Nurjan’s partners:

Ayim is twenty-seven. She lives in Tokmok. Her spouse works in the Border Service of the Kyrgyz Republic. Ayim has a son. Ayim has been fortunate. Due to her husband’s job, she sent her son to a kindergarten and started trading in men’s and women’s shoes. Ayim hopes to obtain this loan and invest the funds to increase the turnover.

Gulnara is 32. She has two children. Since the collapse of Soviet Union, she has been engaged in commerce near a hospital. Now, she plans to sell foodstuffs at school. She needs a loan to purchase goods and foodstuffs to increase the turnover. With the return, she will pay for her daughter’s education.

Anara is fifty. Her husband took part in the Afghan war and now is retired. Anara has three children. Her eldest daughter goes to high school. The rest are little and stay at home with Anara. Anara needs a loan to make a repair in her flat.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of their customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our lending team, Supporters of Kyrgyzstan, at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy more kinds of shoes and socks

loans.name: Florencia

texts.es: La Sra.A. L. Florencia 33 años de edad es conviviente, tiene 02 hijos en edad escolar a raíz de el afán de superación su conviviente tuvo que salir fuera de la ciudad para tratar de Salir adelante  vive en la casa sus cuñados, ella labora vendiendo desayunos, de esa manera trata de salir adelante, solicita el crédito para gastos escolares de sus menores hijos.
texts.en:
Ms. A. L. Florencia is a 33-year-old woman with a live-in partner and 2 school age children. Because of her partner's eagerness for self-improvement, he had to leave the city to try to get ahead. Her siblings-in-law live with her. She sells breakfast to try to get ahead in life. She is requesting this loan for her children's educational expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business investment

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
When she started her business in 2008, Merlinda Furtunato’s goal was making her business grow to support her family.

Merlinda, 25 years old, tills a small rice field, which is 1-hectare (2.5-acres) in size. She wants to have an abundant harvest but lacks capital to buy all the farm supplies. She would like to request a loan of Php 5,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. The loan will really help her to go on in her farming business and to have sustainable income for her family. The loan will help buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Hopefully the income will help her save money to raise her two-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Kanthi

texts.en:
Kanthi is a 48-year-old married woman living with her husband and 3 children, aged from sixteen to twenty-four.  They live in the town of Hikkaduwa, on the southern coast of Sri Lanka.  

She and her husband have a business in which they sell firewood.  Kanthi and her husband are running the business with good help; it has now been in operation for 10 years.  Kanthi is an active lady and she and her husband make a very good team in their business.

She has requested a 40,000 LKR loan from BRAC to help expand the business and buy a new machine to help split firewood.  They hope to continue to see success and increased profits from the new machine.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: to purchase a new firewood splitting machine

loans.name: Alamo

texts.en: Alamo is happy man. He sells engine oil in a tank to his customers. He has been in this business for long and his only challenge in his business is funds and he hopes to overcome this challenge.  He is 38 years old, married with 2 children and his children attend school.  He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell

loans.name: Loida

texts.es: LA SRA. LOIDA VIVE EN LA LOCALIDAD DE EL TORNO DISTANTE A 40 KM DE LA CIUDAD DE SANTA CRUZ, EN EL BARRIO LAS PALMAS, SU ACTIVIDAD PRINCIPAL ES LA VENTA DE MARCOS Y PUERTAS QUE SU ESPOSO FABRICA YA QUE EL ES CARPINTERO Y REALIZA LA CONTRUCCION DE MUEBLES, EN SU PROPIO DOMICILIO, TIENEN 3 HIJOS LO CUALES ESTAN ESTUDIANDO, POR LO QUE SE LE HACE DIFICIL SUSTENTARLO CON LOS INGRESO DE UNO SOLO, POR TAL MOTIVO TIENE QUE AYUDARLE A SU ESPOSO EN LA ECONOMIA, Y ASI APOYAR EN EL HOGAR CON SU GRANITO DE ARENA, SU DESEO ES SER EL DISTRUBUIDOR DIRECTO CON EL CLIENTE, YA  QUE HOY EN DIA TIENE QUE UTILIZAR INTERMEDIARIOS, PARA VENDER SUS PRODUCTOS; SE SIENTE CONTENTA CON LA INSTITUCION POR EL APOYO BRINDADO EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Mrs. Loida lives in the locality of El Torno, 40 kilometers from the city of Santa Cruz, in the neighborhood of Las Palmas. Her main occupation is the sale of doors and door frames that her husband, the carpenter, constructs, along with other types of furniture, in their home. They have 3 children whom are studying, which makes it difficult to sustain their household with only one income. As such, she must help her husband economically and support her family with the sale of concrete. Currently, she has to utilize intermediaries to sell her products but she hopes to become her customers' direct distributor. She is content with the institution for their support in granting her a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wood.

loans.name: Irene

texts.es:
Nuestra socia pertenecen al banco comunal “PEROLNIYOC”; Nuestra socia vive en la provincia de Urubamba perteneciente al departamento del Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la Sra. Irene;   ella tiene 32 años de edad, la socia es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos estudiantes; Nuestra socia es promotora de pronoei; La socia también se dedica a la crianza de animales menores, la socia trabaja en este ministerio público desde hace 4 años, Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para comprar animales menores y para comprar algunos víveres para el hogar.

La socia agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our client belongs to the “PEROLNIYOC” communal bank. She lives in the province of Urubamba, which belongs to the department of Cusco.

Our client is Irene and she is 32 years old. She has a live-in partner and has 2 school-age children. She is a promoter of PRONOEI (acronym for the Peruvian ‘Non-formal program of initial education’). Irene is also involved in raising younger animals. She has worked in the public ministry for more than 4 years. She is requesting the loan to purchase younger animals and to purchase some supplies for the home.

She is grateful and values the support provided by these means. She promises to repay her loan in the established time frame.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Personal expenses

loans.name: Angele

texts.en:
Angele was born in 1961. She is married with four children. Angele has been a businesswoman for a long time because she has almost 18 years of experience in her business. The hours of her daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 2 in the evening.

Now, Angele is requesting a second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business of selling foodstuffs, especially cassava leaves and so on. This loan will help her to satisfy the demands of her customers, which will allow her to earn more profit.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Rwashamaire Tailoring, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
Hard work and determination have made N. Edger what he is today. This all began after abandoning his former teaching profession, which helped him raise the capital that he used to develop his tailoring business which he operates from Nkongoro Trading Centre in Ntungamo.

This seems to be fulfilling for him as he is in position to earn 200,000 UGX on a weekly basis. This has made the 29-year-old married father of two able to cater for his family's needs. He looks forward to achieving his dream of owning a big business in the area and buying himself a car in the future for easy transportation of his business materials. With this loan, he hopes to buy more stock of materials to make good clothing designs for his customers.

loans.use: to buy more stock of materials to make clothing

loans.name: Ya Alimamy

texts.en:
Ya Alimamy is a hardworking businesswoman who has been in business for the past 20 years. She runs a foodstuff and provisions shop in partnership with her husband. Her shop is located in the far west business district in Freetown city. Ya Alimamy and her husband are in their late fifties. They have five children; all of them are now independent.
Ya Alimamy has a very good loan repayment history with Kiva partner, Association for Rural Development. She needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to help her buy more stock for her shop for wholesale purposes. With the proceeds from this loan she wishes to help her grandchildren and their dependants in school.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy various products like soft drinks, dairy products, Pampers, and soups, etc. to sell

loans.name: Digna Margarita

texts.es:
La Señora Digna Margarita es socia del banco comunal Atenas, vive por la parroquia de Sidcay,  la agricultura y ganadería es la ocupación tradicional de sus habitantes la que es solo para autoabastecerse, razón suficiente para que salgan a la ciudad de Cuenca en busca de otras fuentes de trabajo.
 
La Señora. Digna tiene 49 años,  vive en unión libre y tiene  11 hijos, sus primeros 4 hijos son casados y viven  independientemente, sus 7 hijos solteros que tienen  19, 17, 16, 15, 13, 9 y 8 años de edad todos estudian, los 5 primeros en el colegio y sus dos últimos  en la escuela, su esposo trabaja como empleado privado, no tiene casa propia por lo que viven en una casa que les han prestado.

Doña Digna se dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar y aprovecha  ese tiempo para la realizar  guaipe (tela para limpiar), actividad que la realiza hace un año, también cuenta con un su negocio  de salchipapas las que vende en su parroquia hace 6 años. Nuestra socia se encuentra en su quinto crédito que realiza en la fundación Espoir, los cuales le han beneficiado  en su hogar y negocio. El  dinero de su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir para las matriculas de sus hijos y también en la compra de tela para realizar guaipe.
 
Su sueño es  tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Señora Digna Margarita is a member of the Atenas community bank. She lives in Sidcay parish where the traditional work of the local people is agriculture and raising animals so they can be self-sufficient. They go to the city of Cuenca to find other sources of work. Sra. Digna is 49 years old and lives with her common-law partner. She has eleven children: the four oldest are married and have left home, and her seven remaining children (aged 19, 17, 16, 15, 13, 9, and 8) are all students, five in secondary school and the two youngest in primary school. Digna’s husband works as a private employee. They don’t have a house of their own so they live in a house that someone has lent to them. Digna looks after the household and also uses the time to make dusters (cloths for cleaning). She started doing this a year ago. She’s also had a business selling salchipapas (hot dogs and fried potatoes) in the community for six years. This will be Digna’s fifth loan with Kiva partner Fundación Espoir. The loans have helped both her family and her business. The money from this new loan will be used to pay for her children’s education and also for fabric to make the dusters. Digna’s dream is to have a house of her own.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to pay for education and fabric

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda C. is from the village of Faustino, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Luzviminda is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzviminda has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Luzviminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Kurash Ole

texts.en:
Kurash has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last three years.  He is 35 years old and married to Yianai Nakaanita.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the cash to buy 20 young goats, which he will rear and sell later for a profit.

Kurash also is planning to start processing animal skins and hides to sell.

loans.use: To buy 20 young goats, which he will rear and sell later for a profit.

loans.name: Florinda Mariel

texts.es: La señora  Florinda se dedica a la compra y venta de variedad de ropas (chamarras, poleras y otros) desde hace ocho años y medio, tiene una tienda de ropa en el mercado paga alquiler de su puesto,   Tiene casa propia, tiene dos hijos, su esposo es albañil contratista, esta en su tercer ciclo, donde ha demostrado ser responsable en sus pagos con la institución. El crédito lo utilizara  para aumentar su mercadería, surtir mejor su tienda con variedad de ropa de temporada, es una persona muy trabajadora y esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada.
texts.en:
Florinda buys and sells a variety of clothing (jackets, traditional skirts, and others).  She has been doing this for eight and a half years.  She has a clothing store in the market, and she pays rent for her space.  

She has her own house, and she has two children.  Her husband is a contract bricklayer.

She is in her third cycle, and she has demonstrated herself to be responsible with her payments in the institution.  She will use the loan to increase her merchandise and stock her store with a better variety of seasonal clothes.  

She is a very hard-working person, and she is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust they have placed in her.

loans.use: To buy a variety of clothing

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie C. is a single woman who lives in Purok Kalobihan, Barangay Cartagena, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: buying and selling rice, a general store, and farming businesses. Rosemarie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosemarie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to buy rice to resell so that she can continue to save up for future expansion of her business. Rosemarie C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 


About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more rice to sell

loans.name: Lodgie

texts.en:
Lodgie S. is from the village of Extension, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 40 years old. Lodgie is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Lodgie owns and operates a business running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as canned goods, soy sauce and vinegar in a pouch, detergents, and firewood in the local community. Lodgie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lodgie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lodgie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Lodgie is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Lodgie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and increase working capital

loans.name: Ma. Corazon

texts.en:
There is nothing so trashy that God cannot use it. Ma. Corazon L., 43, finished only high school, but that far contradicts what she has accomplished in her life. Ma. Corazon is married to Henry, a regular employee. They have two children; one is in high school and the other in elementary. Ma. Corazon's family resides in Caloocan City, Philippines.

Ma. Corazon presently owns a junk shop and runs a ready-to-wear (RTW) business. She has been in business for ten years now. People in her community serve as Corazon's target market, and every month she earns around Php 8,000. She accepts used bottles and old newspapers for recycling. She also sells clothes which suits the tastes of her neighbors and friends.

But life isn't all about business. Ma. Corazon sees in parallel the needs of her business as well as the needs of her children. Realizing that she needs more than what she can produce at the moment, she would like to apply for Php 38,000 loan. Ma. Corazon will use the money to buy merchandise in bulk for her business. She also intends to buy two computer units and start up a computer shop. 

She aspires for her junk shop to grow, because in the end, it will benefit her family, especially her children.  She faithfully attends weekly fellowship* meeting.

The price of junk items has gone down, and that really poses a business challenge to Ma. Corazon, but she knows that all things eventually work out for the good of God's people. God never treats His children like trash, and neither does Ma. Corazon. She values her children so much, and her desire is  for them to finish schooling and serve God in their lives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: additional bulk merchandise for inventory

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn P. is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Marilyn is married and has 1 school-aged child.  To make a living, Marilyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. 

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.
